 As to God having sex with Mary and the Mormon doctrine of God being a glorified man and one of many gods, Scripture indicates neither God had sex with Mary, nor that God is a glorified man, it is false doctrine. 
 
 From reading other threads, it appears that the person initiating this thread has an aversion to the belief in God, to the belief in Jesus Christ, and to scripture in general, thus as the second responder here notes, this thread is simply trolling. 
 
 Scripture states that the spirit of God came over Mary. To a Christian, this is quite clear, to those opposed and whose objective is to denigrate what is taken up on faith, it is an anathema. Unfortunately for them it is an unanswerable anathema aside from their own opinions. 
 
 Faith is faith. If it were provable would it be faith? When I go to sleep at night, I do so with the faith that if I do not awaken, then my faith will see me through. If I do not awaken, and do not awaken ever, as you atheists and agnostics believe, then is that any great loss, is your passing any great loss? 
 
 From my point of view, I see it as a better thing to have a faith in the afterlife and strive to attain the bar set by Christ than live my life believing that when I'm dead, that's it, and that my only purpose in life is to vilify those who do have that professed faith.

 Ah, but there are LIBERAL FUNDIES too!
 
 Liberal Fundamentalism 
 
 Someone once said to beware of zealots. Yet Jesus Christ was a zealot for the ways of God, and Mother Theresa was certainly a zealot for helping the sick and needy. Being a zealot, then, is not automatically a prescription for hated. Likewise, religious fundamentalism. One can certainly believe in the fundamental teachings of Jesus Christ and Biblical values, practice them, and not be a threat to society or one's neighbors. On the other hand, there's a new and particularly pernicious brand of fundamentalism making the rounds in America today - liberal fundamentalism. 
 
 Liberal Fundamentalism is a failed and destructive philosophical enterprise, replete with a host of anti-Biblical, pseudo-religious doctrines that seeks to elevate the ways and "wisdom" of man above the wisdom and desires of God. Its principle aim is the sacking of traditional Judaic and Christian values and beliefs, which are revisited through suspect liberal "scholarship" or politically-correct dogma in an effort to replace them with the tenets of carnal moral hedonism and the failed social doctrines of today's liberal elitists. 
 
 The genesis of today's liberal fundamentalists was the anti-traditionalist hedonists of the 1960's and 70's. They advocated fornication and "free-love," illegal substance abuse, moral relativism, contempt for authority, and they enjoyed a prosperous America founded on the very hard work and enterprise they sought to distance themselves from. The freedoms they enjoyed were purchased by the blood, sweat and personal sacrifices of the very forefathers they held in contempt. 
 
 Personal responsibility, self-restraint and self-sacrifice are often foreign concepts to them. "Right and wrong," and "good and evil" were arbitrarily revisited, for such concepts had no objective meaning to them. They had no objective rationality for their hedonistic philosophy other than if it "feels good, let's do it." The only righteous cause that qualified for support in their "progressive" mindset was the undermining and revising of traditional American and Judeo-Christian values. They said not to trust anyone "over 30," and now they're over 30 and say, "Trust us, and what we teach!" Thank you, FOXNews.com - University of Colorado Board Votes to Fire Embattled Professor Ward Churchill - Local News | News Articles | National News | US News Ward Churchill. 
 
 One of the most revered mantras of liberal fundamentalism is "equality." The net effect of this experiment, in many instances, was to elevate women via the degradation of men, promote racial equality by instituting race-based preferences and reverse discrimination, engender class warfare against people of means via their socialistic redistribution of wealth schemes (a concept centered in greed for other people's money, rather than relying on one's own personal initiative and work ethic), and elevate wickedness (sodomy, fornication, pornography, and other ungodly issues) to the plateau of respectability at the expense of traditional Godly values. 
 
 Along with the failed liberal concept of equality was the mantra of liberal "tolerance." However, liberal tolerance is not what it appears to be. It is a contradictory, partisan philosophical perspective with its own rigid set of dogmas. It assumes, for instance, a relativistic view of moral and religious knowledge. This assumption has shaped the way many people think about issues such as homosexuality, abortion rights, and religious truth claims, leading them to believe that a liberally tolerant posture concerning these issues is the correct one and that it ought to be reflected in our laws and customs. But this posture is often dogmatic, intolerant, and coercive, for it asserts that there is only one correct view on these issues, and if one does not embrace it, one may likely face public ridicule, demagogic tactics, and perhaps even legal reprisals. Liberal tolerance is therefore neither liberal nor tolerant. 
 
 Rather than truly embrace "freedom," liberal fundamentalists seek to control virtually every aspect of the lives of the masses that are unfortunate enough to be under their fundamentalist rulership. They seek to outlaw SUV's, impose smoking bans while advocating marijuana use, prohibit freedom of religious expression in government and public schools, advocate compulsory training in politically correct opinions and attitudes, seek to enforce Bible bans in schools and the workplace, embrace a de-facto litmus test against pro-life judicial nominees, seek to criminalize pro-life demonstrations through the RICO racketeering statute, try to squelch legitimate religious speech via "hate-speech" laws (note Canada), and generally engage in a wide range of behaviors designed to subvert the U.S. Constitution and traditional American values. 
 
 It is certainly arguable, then, that "progressive" liberal fundamentalism substantially undermines the basic effectiveness of the government and other societal elements of democracy. Despite the idealistic goals of liberalism, attempts to build a utopian liberal society in America have only led to heightened outbreaks of AIDS, VD, porno-related crime, social divisions, divorce, abortion, drug addictions, deficit spending, the welfare state, a crushing tax burden, the breakdown of the family unit, moral depravity, and numerous other such scourges which have resulted in enormous societal suffering and discontent. As a result, liberal fundamentalism is strongly associated with left-wing fanaticism, reverse-racism, anti-intellectualism, elitism, nihilism, godlessness, and societal violence. - Author Unknown

 Penfold gassed it again.
 
 The Birth of Jesus Foretold - Luke Chapter 1
 
 26In the sixth month, God sent the angel Gabriel to Nazareth, a town in Galilee, 27to a virgin pledged to be married to a man named Joseph, a descendant of David. The virgin's name was Mary. 28The angel went to her and said, "Greetings, you who are highly favored! The Lord is with you." 
 29Mary was greatly troubled at his words and wondered what kind of greeting this might be. 30But the angel said to her, "Do not be afraid, Mary, you have found favor with God. 31You will be with child and give birth to a son, and you are to give him the name Jesus. 32He will be great and will be called the Son of the Most High. The Lord God will give him the throne of his father David, 33and he will reign over the house of Jacob forever; his kingdom will never end." 
 
 34"How will this be," Mary asked the angel, "since I am a virgin?" 
 
 35The angel answered, "The Holy Spirit will come upon you, and the power of the Most High will overshadow you. So the holy one to be born will be called[c] the Son of God. 36Even Elizabeth your relative is going to have a child in her old age, and she who was said to be barren is in her sixth month. 37For nothing is impossible with God." 
 
 38"I am the Lord's servant," Mary answered. "May it be to me as you have said." Then the angel left her.
 
 There it is - Mary's approval - "May it be to me as you have said."

 Umm... the KJV is a Protestant translation. Plenty of Protestants use the Apocrypha as well.

The KJV is of course only the third official English translation, following on from the "Great Bible" under Henry the Eighth, and the "Bishop's Bible" of the 1550's. Various adjustments edits and alterations were made, the better to fit the processes of the Anglican church, as they evolved. Whatever truths might be found in that particular version, they're not exactly gospel. emoticon_xgood

 Geeez, now you people are experts on the bible. To be a real expert, however, one has to study it.
 
 You 'critics' like to point out that the original King James had the Apocrypha in it as though that fact compromises its integrity. But several things must be examined to get the factual picture.
 
 First, in the days in which the Bible was translated, the Apocrypha was accepted reading based on its historical value, though not accepted as Scripture by anyone outside of the Catholic church. 
 
 The King James translators therefore placed it between the Old and New Testaments for its historical benefit to its readers. They did not integrate it into the Old Testament text as do the corrupt Alexandrian manuscnpts.
 
 That they rejected the Apocrypha as divine is very obvious by the seven reasons which they gave for not incorporating it into the text. They are as follows:
 
 1. Not one of them is in the Hebrew language, which was alone used by the inspired historians and poets of the Old Testament.
 
 2. Not one of the writers lays any claim to inspiration.
 
 3. These books were never acknowledged as sacred Scriptures by the Jewish Church, and therefore were never sanctioned by our Lord.
 
 4. They were not allowed a place among the sacred books, during the first four centuries of the Christian Church.
 
 5. They contain fabulous statements, and statements which contradict not only the canonical Scriptures, but themselves; as when, in the two Books of Maccabees, Antiochus Epiphanes is made to die three different deaths in as many different places.
 
 6. The Apocrypha inculcates doctrines at variance with the Bible, such as prayers for the dead and sinless perfection.
 
 7. It teaches immoral practices, such as lying, suicide, assassination and magical incantation.
 
 As usual, ya'll need to learn a little more in order to qualify as a 'critic.'

6. The Apocrypha inculcates doctrines at variance with the Bible, such as prayers for the dead and sinless perfection.
 

 
 Prayers for the dead are not forbidden in the Bible, and indeed feature in Paul's second letter to Timothy, where he offers prayers for Onesiphorous. It was also practised widely in the early church. Once again we come up against the nonsense of sola scriptura.
 
 Internal contradiction also features in the canonical books of the Bible, as with the two versions of the creation story in Genesis. The gospels also feature divergent accounts. That doesn't make them worthless, or mean that their writing wasn't divinely inspired. What it does make them is fallible, but the idea of scriptural infallibility is as dangerous as that of Papal infallibility.

 Here is the passage in question Jo, 
 2 Timothy 1:16-18 (New International Version)
 
 16May the Lord show mercy to the household of Onesiphorus, because he often refreshed me and was not ashamed of my chains. 17On the contrary, when he was in Rome, he searched hard for me until he found me. 18May the Lord grant that he will find mercy from the Lord on that day! You know very well in how many ways he helped me in Ephesus.
 Prayers for the dead from the Catholic and Anglican perspective usually means praying for the salvation of those who have died in the flesh in an unsaved condition, correct? That isn't what Paul is doing here for Oniphorus or for his family. He never prays for anyones salvation at all but for mercy to his household and for him on that day.

 On that day i.e. on the day of judgement. We pray because we don't know the condition of anyone's soul at the point of death, and we pray that God will have mercy on those who have died, just as we pray for mercy for our own sins while we are still alive. The number of people recognised as saved is tiny, and the Anglican church stopped trying to officially identify saints (those who are saved) over 300 years ago.

I'm Mormon. We do *NOT* believe that it was sexual intercourse that produced Jesus. We *DO* believe in science. 
 
 Yes, we believe that we are in the image of God, down to the anatomical specifics, but not necessarily the same patterns. Erections? We have no doctrine about that. What's the point?
 
 We just believe in science more than scientists. God is omnipotent because he knows science a heck of a lot better than we do. All miracles that He does, according to us, are not "magic", but using higher rules of science that we do not understand. Ancient Mayans thought that muskets were magic. they aren't. The Mayans just didn't understand how they worked. Same with God. We believe that God doesn't violate the laws of science. He doesn't need to. If He wants a woman to concieve, He doesn't need physical intimacy to accomplish that. 
 
 That was 2000 years before the "emryo implant" thing we have today. Today, we don't need intercourse to have children anymore. (But it is much cheaper!) Ta-DAAA! A miracle!

post_info.post_title: Okay, so i'm WAYYY late to post, but....

in keeping with the current thread:
 
 I believe in a God to whom time has no meaning. "Time is measured only unto man." So, I believe that it doesn't matter when somebody dies, we can pray for them whenever.
 
 We know scientifically that time is relative, not an absolute. Why do we separate what we know scientifically from what we know religiously? Time is all one to God, in my belief, therefore it's just as helpful to pray for the dead as for the living.
Thanks romebigred.That clears a lot of stuff up.

in keeping with the current thread:
 
 I believe in a God to whom time has no meaning. "Time is measured only unto man." So, I believe that it doesn't matter when somebody dies, we can pray for them whenever.
 
 We know scientifically that time is relative, not an absolute. Why do we separate what we know scientifically from what we know religiously? Time is all one to God, in my belief, therefore it's just as helpful to pray for the dead as for the living.

 
 I invite you to tell me a little more about this 'god' who was once a man and through his own effort became a god, having a wife, that rules over this particular little acre of the universe.....

I'm Mormon. We do *NOT* believe that it was sexual intercourse that produced Jesus. 

 
 Do you folks believe Jesus is a created being?

I've only got a second, but I hate how this always happens. I believe differently than many others who believe in the Bible, and because of that, there's the typical hostility toward those who don't "fit the mould." Scorning somebody because they're different? Please assure me that's not what you are doing in your post.
 
 I really hope someday the world progresses beyond this kind of preemptive scorn. Ghandi once said, "I like your Christ, but I don't like your Christians. They are so unlike Christ." I think this is the core of it: Christ preached unity, friendship and peace. "Love thy neighbor as thyself." (Matthew 22:39) "Love one another." (John 13:34-35) He didn't say, "Love thy neighbor except the heathen."," or "Love one another as long as your they believe the same as you do."
 
 
I invite you to tell me a little more about this 'god' who was once a man and through his own effort became a god, having a wife, that rules over this particular little acre of the universe.....
 You could at least pretend to have respect for other people's deeply held beliefs, couldn't you? And btw, you're pretty far off on this comment. Forget about the God you've already decided that I believe in. Let me tell you about the God I actually believe in. He is the God of the Bible, an omnipotent, omniscient being who rule the entire universe (--not just some little acre. You might consider checking your sources). He is eternal. He created all that is and was. He loves us all unconditionally. He sent His only begotten Son to save us all from our sins. 
 
 One can make anything sound nuts. Watch this: Christmas is a holiday where families sit around a dead tree in the living room eating candy out of decorative socks, and pull colored paper off of boxes. Weird.
 When you know more about it, it sounds much less weird. To you and me, it's a normal and integral part of winter, and celebrating the birth of Christ. 
 
 
Do you folks believe Jesus is a created being?
 We believe that His body was created by God. We do not believe that His being, His essence was created. It is eternal.
 
 I really hope I'm not coming off sounding harsh here. I'm so used to be reviled as soon as I post the words, "I'm Mormon." I don't intend to spend a lot of time dwelling on The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints here. (That's the real name of the church.) This thread isn't about us, and I don't want to detract from the topic at hand. I'm thinking of creating a new thread to clear up many misconceptions about my religion. I'll let you know when I do.

 I have attended church, 3 hours, every Sunday all my life, as an active practicing LDS (Mormon). When I was 7, my Dad became a 2nd counselor (almost like assistant minister.) When I was 12, he became a Bishop (head of the congregation.) Since then he has served on the High Council. He was my main religious teacher. Beyond this, I attended a 1 hour class in my religion every day of the week from 6am-7am before school. At the age of 17, I moved on to the college-credit classes of CES Insitutue on LDS (mormonism) like many that are offered around the country near colleges. At the age of 18, I served as High Council liason, a 15-hour a week responsibility. This so far gives me four six years of official schooling in my religion, beyond that of Sunday school and being raised by a Bishop/High Priest. 
 
 Then at 19, I served a two year proselyting mission for my church in Italy, where I taught our religion to Catholic priests, and seminarians, men with doctorates in scripture and theology. I also taught men who had doctorates in ancient writings, and had read the scriptures in original languages of the oldest texts known to man. (Hebrew, Aramaic, and Greek) You better believe I had to know my stuff to have answers to their questions. 
 
 When I returned, I went off to BYU, the University run by the LDS church, and I have since received another three years' study in BYU religion classes. This puts me at nine years' formal education in Mormonism, six of which were at the college level.
 
 I promise you, I am putting forth the official doctrines of my church.
